senses.definition: wanting to do something or wanting something to happen very much

examples.en: John was very keen to help.

examples.cf: keen for somebody/something to do something
examples.en: Her parents were keen for her to go to university.
He is keen for the deal to proceed.
We are keen that our school should get involved too.
I wasn't too keen on going to the party.

senses.definition: enthusiastic about an activity or idea, etc.

examples.en: a keen sportsman/gardener
one of the keenest supporters of the team
She was a star pupil—keen, confident and bright.

senses.definition: liking somebody/something very much; very interested in somebody/something

examples.en: They've been on a few dates together and Naomi seems really keen.
Tom's very keen on Anna.
He's particularly keen on football.
Sally's quite keen on the idea.
She's not keen on being told what to do.

senses.definition: quick to understand

examples.en: a keen mind/intellect

senses.definition: strong or deep

examples.en: a keen sense of tradition
He took a keen interest in his grandson's education.

senses.definition: highly developed

examples.en: Dogs have a keen sense of smell.
My friend has a keen eye for (= is good at noticing) a bargain.

senses.definition: involving people competing very hard with each other for something

examples.en: There is keen competition for places at the college.
They were keen rivals.
It was the subject of keen debate.

senses.definition: kept low in order to compete with other prices

examples.en: The company hopes its keen pricing policy will increase sales.

senses.definition: extremely cold
having a sharp edge or point
wanting very much to do well at something; enthusiastic
liking something/somebody very much; very interested in something

examples.en: He's mad keen on planes.

senses.definition: to make a loud, high sad sound, when somebody has died
to continue to have something and not give it back or throw it away

examples.en: He kept all her letters.
She handed the waiter a hundred dollar bill and told him to keep the change.
Always keep a backup of the file.

senses.definition: to put or store something in a particular place

examples.en: Keep your passport in a safe place.

senses.definition: to save something for somebody

examples.en: Please keep a seat for me.
The man in the shop said he'd keep it for me until Friday.
Please keep me a seat.

senses.definition: to stay in a particular condition or position; to make somebody/something do this

examples.en: We huddled together to keep warm.
I could not keep silent any longer.
The notice said ‘Keep off (= Do not walk on) the grass’.
Keep left along the wall.
The doctors worked miracles to keep him alive.
Winning the contract means they can now keep the factory open.
She kept the children amused for hours.
Keep your PIN safe.
He kept his coat on.
Don't keep us in suspense—what happened next?
She had trouble keeping her balance.
I'm very sorry to keep you waiting.

senses.definition: to continue doing something; to do something repeatedly

examples.en: Keep smiling!
Why does everyone keep saying that?
Things just keep getting worse.
Don't keep on interrupting me!

senses.definition: to know something and not tell it to anyone

examples.en: Can you keep a secret?
She kept her past secret from us all.

senses.definition: to do what you have promised to do; to go where you have agreed to go

examples.en: She kept her promise to visit them.
Mary kept her word and Henry was never informed.
He failed to keep his appointment at the clinic.

senses.definition: to write down something as a record

examples.en: She kept a diary for over twenty years.
We keep a record of all complaints that we receive.
Keep a note of where each item can be found.
I kept a weekly account of my workload and activities.

senses.definition: to own and care for animals

examples.en: to keep bees/goats/hens
My grandmother kept chickens in her back yard.
Residents are not allowed to keep pets.

senses.definition: to own and manage a shop or restaurant

examples.en: Her father kept a grocer's shop.

senses.definition: to provide what is necessary for somebody to live; to support somebody by paying for food, etc.

examples.en: He scarcely earns enough to keep himself and his family.

senses.definition: to delay somebody

examples.en: You're an hour late—what kept you?
I won't keep you long. I've just got a couple of quick questions.

senses.definition: used to ask or talk about somebody’s health

examples.en: How is your mother keeping?
We're all keeping well.

senses.definition: to remain in good condition

examples.en: Finish off the pie—it won't keep.
Milk and cream should keep quite well in a fridge.
‘I'd love to hear about it, but I'm late already.’ ‘That's OK—it'll keep (= I can tell you about it later).’

senses.definition: to protect somebody from something

examples.en: May the Lord bless you and keep you (= used in prayers in the Christian Church).
His only thought was to keep the boy from harm.

senses.definition: to guard or protect the goal or wicket
to make an effort to live normally when you are in a difficult situation or when you have experienced great pain and difficulty

examples.en: You just have to keep yourself busy and keep going.

senses.definition: used to encourage somebody to continue doing something

examples.en: Keep going, Sarah—you're nearly there.

senses.definition: to be enough for somebody until they get what they are waiting for

examples.en: Have an apple to keep you going till dinner time.

senses.definition: food, clothes and all the other things that a person needs to live; the cost of these things

examples.en: It's about time you got a job to earn your keep.

senses.definition: a large strong tower, built as part of an old castle

examples.en: He made his way up a flight of steep stairs and into the main keep of the castle.

senses.definition: to do useful or helpful things in return for being allowed to live or stay somewhere

examples.en: He was willing to earn his keep.

senses.definition: to be worth the amount of time or money that is being spent

examples.en: He felt he no longer deserved such a high salary. He just wasn't earning his keep.
All this new technology will have to earn its keep.

senses.definition: forever

examples.en: Is it yours for keeps or does he want it back?

senses.definition: a piece of metal with a special shape used for locking a door, starting a car, etc.

examples.en: to put/turn the key in the lock
He inserted the key in the lock and let himself into the house.
the car keys
a set/bunch of keys
the spare key to the front door
We'll have a duplicate key cut (= made).
Luckily Dad has keys for my house.
There's a special key for winding up this clock.

senses.definition: a thing that makes you able to understand or achieve something

examples.en: Persistence is the key if you want to get a job.
The key to success is preparation.
First-time voters could hold the key to the election result.
The driver of the car probably holds the key to solving the crime.
Language is the key to understanding those around you.
The key is, how long can the federal government control the inflation rate?

senses.definition: any of the buttons that you press to operate a computer, phone or typewriter

examples.en: Press the return key to enter the information.
You can use the arrow keys on the keyboard instead.
He began tapping on the keys of his laptop.

senses.definition: any of the wooden or metal parts that you press to play a piano and some other musical instruments

examples.en: His hands flew over the piano keys.

senses.definition: a set of related notes, based on a particular note. Pieces of music are usually written mainly using a particular key.

examples.en: a sonata in the key of E flat major
This piece changes key many times.

senses.definition: a set of answers to exercises or problems

examples.en: Check your answers in the key at the back of the book.

senses.definition: an explanation of the symbols used on a map or plan

examples.en: You can find the symbols in the key at the bottom of the page.

idioms.word: (keep something/put something/be) under lock and key

senses.definition: locked up safely somewhere; in prison

examples.en: We keep our valuables under lock and key.
I will not rest until the murderer is under lock and key.
Prisoners are kept under lock and key 24 hours a day.

senses.definition: most important; essential

examples.en: the key issue/factor/point
a key element/component/part/feature
He was a key figure in the campaign.
Both are key players in the peace process.
She played a key role in the dispute.
‘Caution’ is the key word in this situation.
His contribution could be key.
Good communication is key to our success.
Better training for our staff has been key to improving the service.

senses.definition: to put information into a computer using a keyboard

examples.en: I was busy keying data.
Key in your password.
The information is then keyed into a computer.

senses.definition: to deliberately damage a car by scratching it with a key
the set of keys for operating a computer or typewriter, or the set of letters that you can touch to write on a smartphone or tablet

examples.en: The program locks the keyboard until a password is given.
keyboard shortcuts

senses.definition: the set of black and white keys on a piano or other musical instrument

examples.en: a piano keyboard

senses.definition: an electronic musical instrument that has keys like a piano and can be made to play in different styles or to sound like different instruments

examples.en: She plays keyboard and guitar.
He played the song on his keyboard.
The recording features Herbie Hancock on keyboard.
She sat down at the keyboard and started to play.

senses.definition: to type information into a computer
to hit somebody/something with your foot

examples.en: Stop kicking—it hurts!
She was punched and kicked by her attackers.
The boys were kicking a ball around in the yard.
Vandals had kicked the door down.
She had to kick the door open because her hands were full.
She kicked at the loose pebbles by the roadside.

senses.definition: to move your legs as if you were kicking something

examples.en: The child was dragged away, kicking and screaming.
The dancers kicked their legs in the air.

senses.definition: to be annoyed with yourself because you have done something stupid, missed an opportunity, etc.

examples.en: He'll kick himself when he finds out he could have had the job.

senses.dis_g: (in sports such as football (soccer) and rugby)
senses.definition: to score points by kicking the ball

examples.en: to kick a penalty/goal
He kicked 23 points, ensuring victory for New Zealand.

senses.definition: to stop doing something harmful that you have done for a long time

examples.en: He had been smoking for 15 years and wanted to kick the habit.
to kick drugs/the booze

senses.definition: very active, healthy or popular

examples.en: My mother is still alive and kicking.

idioms.word: beat/kick (the) hell out of somebody/something | knock hell out of somebody/something

senses.definition: to hit somebody/something very hard

examples.en: He was a dirty player and loved to kick hell out of the opposition.

senses.definition: to act in a way that is aggressive or full of energy
to succeed or win in an impressive way
to punish or defeat somebody
to die
to delay dealing with a problem

examples.en: This is another attempt to kick the can down the road and leave it to the next generation.

senses.definition: to have nothing to do while you are waiting for somebody/something

examples.en: We were kicking our heels, waiting for some customers.

senses.definition: if you drag somebody kicking and screaming to do something, they only do it with great protests because they don't really want to do it at all

examples.en: The president had to be dragged kicking and screaming to the signing ceremony.

senses.definition: to treat somebody badly or fail to give them help when they need it

idioms.word: kick something into the long grass/into touch

senses.definition: to reject something or treat it as not important; to stop dealing with a problem

examples.en: He tends to deal with disputes by kicking them into the long grass.

senses.definition: to start to behave badly and refuse to accept any discipline or control

variants.html: (North American English kick the tires)

senses.definition: to test the quality of something to see whether it is suitable for you before you buy it

idioms.word: kick up a fuss, stink, etc.

senses.definition: to complain loudly about something

examples.en: They’ll usually give you your money back if you threaten to kick up a stink.

senses.definition: to be relaxed and enjoy yourself
to move somebody to a job that seems to be more important but that actually has less power or influence
to continue to hurt somebody when they are already defeated, etc.
a movement with the foot or the leg, usually to hit something with the foot

examples.en: the first kick of the game
He barely got a kick of the ball the whole match.
She gave him a kick on the shin.
If the door won't open, give it a kick.
He aimed a kick at the dog.

senses.definition: a strong feeling of excitement and pleasure

examples.en: I get a kick out of driving fast cars.
He gets his kicks from hurting other people.
What do you do for kicks?

senses.definition: the strong effect that a drug or an alcoholic drink has

examples.en: This drink has quite a kick.

senses.definition: a soft shoe that you wear for sports or as informal clothing

examples.en: The actor wore denim, a simple tee and a nice pair of kicks.

idioms.word: a kick in the pants/up the backside

senses.definition: if you think somebody needs a kick in the pants or a kick up the backside you think they need to be strongly encouraged to do something or behave better
something that hurts somebody/something emotionally; a great disappointment

examples.en: The job losses are a kick in the teeth for the union.

senses.definition: a child or young person

examples.en: Do you have any kids?
How are the kids (= your children)?
A bunch of kids were hanging around outside.
a gang/group of kids
college/school kids
street kids who rely on their ingenuity to keep alive
You're acting like a little kid!
I remember reading with my grandmother as a young kid of 6.
I'm looking forward to getting home to the wife and kids.
Here are some fun ways to teach your kids about healthy eating.
The kids love playing outside in the mud.
The game is aimed at kids of all ages.

senses.definition: a young goat
soft leather made from the skin of a young goat

examples.en: a pair of white kid gloves

idioms.word: handle/treat, etc. somebody with kid gloves

senses.definition: to deal with somebody in a very careful way so that you do not offend or upset them

examples.en: Treat her with kid gloves—she's very sensitive.

variants.html: (North American English kid stuff)

senses.definition: something that is so easy to do or understand that it is thought to be not very serious or only suitable for children

examples.en: That was kids' stuff compared with what lies ahead.
The movie is pure kids' stuff from beginning to end.

idioms.word: a/the new kid on the block

senses.definition: a person who is new to a place, an organization, etc.

examples.en: Despite his six years in politics, he was still regarded by many as the new kid on the block.

senses.definition: to tell somebody something that is not true, especially as a joke

examples.en: I thought he was kidding when he said he was going out with a rock star.
I didn't mean it. I was only kidding.
I'm not kidding you. It does work.

senses.definition: to allow somebody/yourself to believe something that is not true

examples.en: They're kidding themselves if they think it's going to be easy.
I tried to kid myself (that) everything was normal.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something is true or that you agree with something that somebody has just said

examples.en: ‘It's cold!’ ‘No kidding!’

senses.definition: used to show that you mean what you are saying

examples.en: I want the money back tomorrow. No kidding.

idioms.word: you’re kidding | you must be kidding

senses.definition: used to show that you are very surprised at something that somebody has just said

examples.en: She fired you? You're kidding! Why?

senses.definition: a person’s younger sister/brother
to take somebody away illegally and keep them as a prisoner, especially in order to get money or something else for returning them

examples.en: Two businessmen have been kidnapped by terrorists.
The terrorists were planning to kidnap one of the president’s sons.

senses.definition: either of the two organs in the body that remove waste products from the blood and produce urine

examples.en: a kidney infection

senses.definition: the kidneys of some animals that are cooked and eaten

examples.en: steak and kidney pie

senses.definition: to make somebody/something die

examples.en: Cancer kills thousands of people every year.
Tiredness while driving can kill.
Dozens of civilians were killed or injured in the attack.
She was nearly killed by a car bomb.
Both members of the crew were killed instantly when the missile hit their aircraft.
Three soldiers were killed in action (= while fighting) yesterday.
She tried to kill me!
The terrorists threatened to kill the hostages.
I bought a spray to kill the weeds.
My mother will kill me (= be very angry with me) when she finds out.
He tried to kill himself with sleeping pills.
Don't kill yourself trying to get the work done by tomorrow. It can wait.

senses.definition: to destroy something or make it less good; to make something stop

examples.en: to kill a rumour
She claims that social media kills relationships.
The defeat last night killed the team's chances of qualifying.

senses.definition: to switch off a light or engine; to stop a computer program or process

examples.en: She killed the engine and climbed out.
The only way to kill the process is to reboot the computer.

senses.definition: to cause somebody pain

examples.en: My feet are killing me.

senses.definition: to make somebody laugh a lot

examples.en: Stop it! You're killing me!

senses.definition: used to tell somebody not to ask questions or try to find out about things that do not involve them
wearing the kind of clothes that will make people notice and admire you

idioms.word: have time on your hands | have time to kill

senses.definition: to have nothing to do or not be busy
used to describe the very angry or unpleasant way somebody is/was looking at you

examples.en: If looks could kill, she thought, seeing the expression that came over his face when he saw her, she’d be dead on the pavement.
I don’t know what I’ve done to upset him, but if looks could kill…

idioms.word: kill the goose that lays the golden egg/eggs

senses.definition: to destroy something that would make you rich, successful, etc.
to do something really well

examples.en: She always kills it on stage.
The team has been killing it on the pitch this season!

senses.definition: used to say that what you are going to do will either be very successful or fail completely

idioms.word: kill time | kill an hour, a couple of hours, etc.

senses.definition: to spend time doing something that is not important while you are waiting for something else to happen

examples.en: We killed time playing cards.

idioms.word: kill two birds with one stone

senses.definition: to achieve two things at the same time with one action
to be so kind to somebody/something that you in fact harm them
to laugh a lot

examples.en: He was killing himself laughing.

senses.definition: an act of killing, especially when an animal is hunted or killed

examples.en: A cat often plays with a mouse before the kill.
The plane prepared to move in for the kill.
I was in at the kill when she finally lost her job (= present at the end of an unpleasant process).

senses.definition: an animal that has been hunted and killed

examples.en: lions feeding on their kill
vultures sensing a fresh kill

senses.definition: an act of killing somebody deliberately

examples.en: Their leader condemned the torture and killing of innocent civilians.
The mass killing (= killing of a large number of people) occurred when soldiers opened fire on protesters.
He is responsible for the brutal killing of thousands of animals.
No motive for the killing has yet been established.

senses.definition: to make a lot of money quickly

examples.en: She made a killing on the stock market.
Investors are set to make a killing from the sell-off.

senses.definition: making you very tired

examples.en: a killing schedule

variants.html: (US English kilometer)

senses.definition: a unit for measuring distance; 1 000 metres

examples.en: The industrial estate is 6 kilometres from the city centre.
She had been driving at 110 kilometres per hour.
Monaco is only two square kilometres in size.

senses.definition: a group of people or things that are the same in some way; a particular variety or type

examples.en: three kinds of cakes/cake
What kind of house do you live in?
They sell all kinds of things.
I need to buy paper and pencils, that kind of thing.
His diet's terrible—burgers, chips, pizzas, that kind of stuff.
I'm the kind of person who hates to do anything wrong.
We have the same kind of car.
I'll never have that kind of money (= as much money as that).
He wouldn't say anything about it. He's not that kind of man.
This kind of exercise is very popular.
Exercises of this kind are very popular.
music of all/various/different kinds
The school is the first of its kind in Britain.
Would you like a drink of some kind?
The regions differ in size, but not in kind.

senses.definition: consisting of goods or services, not money

examples.en: As well as his salary, he gets benefits in kind.

senses.definition: with the same thing

examples.en: She insulted him and he responded in kind.

senses.definition: used to show that something you are saying is not exact

examples.en: I had a kind of feeling this might happen.

senses.definition: slightly; in some ways

examples.en: That made me feel kind of stupid.
I like him, kind of.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that the situation is very different from what has been said

examples.en: ‘I was terrible!’ ‘You were nothing of the kind.’

senses.definition: not as good as it could be

examples.en: You're making progress of a kind.

senses.definition: very similar

examples.en: They're two of a kind—both workaholics!

senses.definition: the only one like this

examples.en: My father was one of a kind—I'll never be like him.

senses.definition: something like what has been said

examples.en: ‘He's resigning.’ ‘I'd suspected something of the kind.’

senses.definition: caring about others; gentle, friendly and generous

examples.en: a very kind and helpful person
a kind heart/face
a kind action/gesture/comment
You've been very kind.
kind to animals
Soft water is kinder to your hair.
The weather was very kind to us.
Was it kind to let her find out this way?
He was kind enough to take time out of his busy schedule to come here today.
I think it was very kind of her.

examples.cf: it is kind of somebody to do something
examples.en: It was really kind of you to help me.
Thank you for your kind words.
The poems are reprinted here by kind permission of the author.
‘Do have another.’ ‘That's very kind of you (= thank you).’
We need a kinder, gentler society.
If an animal is badly injured, often the kindest thing to do is to destroy it painlessly.

senses.definition: used to make a polite request or give an order

examples.en: Would you be kind enough to close the window?

senses.definition: the male ruler of an independent state that has a royal family

examples.en: the kings and queens of England
the French king
to be crowned king
King George V

senses.definition: a person, an animal or a thing that is thought to be the best or most important of a particular type

examples.en: the king of comedy
The lion is the king of the jungle.

senses.definition: used in compounds with the names of animals or plants to describe a very large type of the thing mentioned

examples.en: a king penguin

senses.definition: the most important piece used in the game of chess, that can move one square in any direction
a playing card with the picture of a king on it
a very large amount of money
the person considered to be the best, most famous or successful in a particular place or area of activity
a country that has a king or queen as head of state (= official leader of the country)

examples.en: the United Kingdom
the kingdom of God (= heaven)

senses.definition: an area controlled by a particular person or where a particular thing or idea is important
one of the three traditional divisions of the natural world

examples.en: the animal, vegetable and mineral kingdoms

senses.definition: one of the five major groups into which all living things are organized
to completely destroy somebody/something with an explosion

examples.en: The truck was blown to kingdom come.

senses.definition: forever

examples.en: He’ll talk till kingdom come if you let him.

senses.definition: to touch somebody with your lips as a sign of love or sexual desire or when saying hello or goodbye

examples.en: They stood in a doorway kissing (= kissing each other).
Do people in Britain kiss when they meet?
Go and kiss your mother goodnight.
He bent forward to kiss her cheek.
She kissed him on both cheeks.
He lifted the trophy up and kissed it.

senses.definition: to gently move or touch something

examples.en: The sunlight kissed the warm stones.

senses.definition: a way of referring to somebody talking publicly, usually for money, about a past sexual relationship with somebody famous

variants.text: (North American English kiss somebody’s ass, kiss ass)
variants.html: (North American English kiss somebody’s ass, kiss ass)

senses.definition: to be very nice to somebody in order to persuade them to help you or to give you something
to take away the pain of an injury by kissing it

examples.en: Come here and let me kiss it better.

idioms.word: kiss something goodbye | kiss goodbye to something

senses.definition: to accept that you will lose something or be unable to do something

examples.en: Well, you can kiss goodbye to your chances of promotion.

senses.definition: the act of kissing somebody/something

examples.en: Come here and give me a kiss!
a kiss on the cheek
We were greeted with hugs and kisses.
As the train drew away he blew her a kiss (= kissed his hand and pretended to blow the kiss towards her).

senses.definition: an event that seems good, but is certain to make something else fail

examples.en: An award can be the kiss of death for a writer.
That TV commercial was the kiss of death to his career as a serious actor.

senses.definition: a method of helping somebody who has stopped breathing to breathe again by placing your mouth on theirs and forcing air into their lungs
to kiss somebody suddenly or secretly

a US heavy metal band which formed in 1972. Members of the band painted their faces, coloured their hair and performed in a wild way on stage. This included destroying guitars, breathing fire and letting false blood come from their mouths. Their albums have included KISS (1974), Unmasked (1980) and Carnival of Souls (1997).
a set of tools or equipment that you use for a particular purpose

examples.en: a drum kit

senses.definition: a set of parts ready to be made into something

examples.en: a kit for a model plane
She built the doll’s house from a kit.

senses.definition: a set of clothes and equipment that you use for a particular activity

examples.en: sports kit
The soldiers packed tents and kits to move to new positions.

senses.definition: to take your clothes off
everything

examples.en: I had new clothes, a new hairstyle—the whole caboodle.

senses.definition: a first name for boys, short for Christopher
a room in which meals are cooked or prepared

examples.en: We ate at the kitchen table.
the kitchen floor/window/door
a stainless steel kitchen sink
He stabbed her with a kitchen knife.
The house has a fully fitted kitchen with custom-built units.

senses.definition: a very large number of things, probably more than is necessary

examples.en: We seem to take everything but the kitchen sink when we go camping.

idioms.word: if you can’t stand the heat (get out of the kitchen)

senses.definition: used to tell somebody to stop trying to do something if they find it too difficult, especially in order to suggest that they are less able than other people
the joint between the top and bottom parts of the leg where it bends in the middle

examples.en: a knee injury
I had knee surgery three years ago.
Bend your knees until you feel your thigh muscles working.
I grazed my knee when I fell.
He went down on one knee and asked her to marry him.
She was on her knees scrubbing the kitchen floor.
Everyone was down on (their) hands and knees (= crawling on the floor) looking for the ring.
He fell to his knees and begged for mercy.
My knees were knocking (= I was frightened).

senses.definition: the part of a piece of clothing that covers the knee

examples.en: I brushed the dust from the knees of my trousers.
These jeans are torn at the knee.
a knee patch

senses.definition: the top surface of the upper part of the legs when you are sitting down

examples.en: Come and sit on Daddy's knee.

senses.definition: when you were very young

examples.en: I learnt these songs at my mother's knee.

senses.definition: an excellent person or thing

examples.en: She thinks she's the bee's knees (= she has a very high opinion of herself).

senses.definition: to defeat somebody, especially in a war
to badly affect an organization, etc. so that it can no longer function

examples.en: The strikes brought the industry to its knees.
The fuel shortage brought the country to its knees within weeks.

senses.definition: if you ask for something on bended knee(s), you ask for it in a very anxious and/or humble way (= showing you think you are less important than the person you are asking)

examples.en: I’d go down on bended knee if I thought she’d change her mind.

senses.definition: to punish somebody by making them lie on top of your knee and hitting their bottom
to kneel on one knee in public in order to protest about the unfair treatment of black people

examples.en: Officers at the rally were seen taking a knee in solidarity with the demonstrators.

senses.definition: hardly able to stand because of emotion, fear, illness, etc.

examples.en: His sudden smile made her go weak at the knees.

senses.definition: to hit or push somebody/something with your knee

examples.en: He kneed his attacker in the groin.

senses.definition: a sharp blade (= metal edge) with a handle, used for cutting or as a weapon

examples.en: knives and forks
a sharp knife
a bread knife (= one for cutting bread)
The aim is to deter young people from carrying knives.
He had been stabbed repeatedly with a kitchen knife.
a plan to tackle knife crime
She was murdered in a frenzied knife attack.

senses.definition: the situation has become so bad that people are preparing to make one person take the blame, for example by taking away their job

examples.en: The knives are out for the chancellor.

senses.definition: easily; without meeting any difficulty

idioms.word: put/stick the knife in | put/stick the knife into somebody

senses.definition: to behave towards somebody in an unfriendly way and try to harm them
to say or do something unkind deliberately; to make somebody who is unhappy feel even more unhappy

examples.en: Marcia laughed as she twisted the knife still deeper.
Just to twist the knife, the filmmakers have provided a surprise ending.

senses.definition: having a medical operation

examples.en: He is to go under the surgeon's knife again on Thursday.

senses.definition: to injure or kill somebody with a knife

examples.en: She knifed him in the back.

senses.definition: to hit a door, etc. in order to attract attention

examples.en: He knocked three times and waited.
I knocked on the door and went straight in.
Somebody was knocking on the window.

senses.definition: to hit something hard, often by accident

examples.en: Be careful you don't knock your head on this low beam.
Her hand knocked against the glass.
She dropped the pile of books when he accidentally knocked her shoulder.

senses.definition: to hit something so that it moves or breaks

examples.en: He'd knocked over a glass of water.
I knocked the nail into the wall.
They had to knock the door down to get in.
He had knocked one of the pictures off the wall.
The boys were knocking (= kicking) a ball around in the back yard.
The criticism had knocked (= damaged) her self-esteem.

senses.definition: to put somebody/something into a particular state by hitting them/it

examples.en: The blow knocked me flat.
He was knocked senseless by the blow.
She knocked my drink flying.
The two rooms had been knocked into one (= the wall between them had been knocked down).

senses.definition: to make a hole in something by hitting it hard

examples.en: They managed to knock a hole in the wall.

senses.definition: if your heart knocks, it beats hard; if your knees knock, they shake, for example from fear

examples.en: My heart was knocking wildly.

senses.definition: to make a regular sound of metal hitting metal, especially because there is something wrong
to criticize somebody/something, especially when it happens unfairly

examples.en: The newspapers are always knocking the England team.
It may sound pretty childish, but don't knock it until you've tried it.

senses.definition: to force people to stop arguing and behave in a sensible way

idioms.word: beat/knock the (living) daylights out of somebody

senses.definition: to hit somebody very hard several times and hurt them very much

examples.en: Get out or I’ll beat the living daylights out of you!

idioms.word: beat/kick (the) hell out of somebody/something | knock hell out of somebody/something

senses.definition: to hit somebody/something very hard

examples.en: He was a dirty player and loved to kick hell out of the opposition.

senses.definition: to surprise or impress somebody very much
to train somebody so that they do a particular job, task, etc. well

examples.en: It took him just two weeks to knock the new recruits into shape.

senses.definition: to make something more acceptable, organized or successful

examples.en: I've got all the information together but it still needs knocking into shape.
It shouldn’t take long to get the company back into shape.

senses.definition: to affect somebody very deeply

examples.en: The business over the lawsuit had really knocked her for six.

senses.definition: used to threaten somebody that you will hit them
to impress somebody very much

examples.en: You look fabulous—you'll knock ’em dead tonight.

idioms.word: knock somebody/something into a cocked hat

senses.definition: to be very much better than somebody/something

examples.en: She knocks the rest of the cast into a cocked hat.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody to stop making a noise, annoying you, etc.

examples.en: Knock it off, kids—I’m trying to work.

senses.definition: to make somebody lose their position as somebody/something successful or admired

examples.en: A lot of teams are looking to knock us off our perch.

senses.definition: to stop something from happening; to stop doing something

examples.en: The recession knocked on the head any idea of expanding the company.
By eleven o’clock we were all tired so we knocked it on the head.

variants.html: (British English touch wood)

senses.definition: used when talking about your previous good luck or your hopes for the future, to avoid bringing bad luck

examples.en: I've been driving for over 20 years and never had an accident—knock on wood!

senses.definition: to surprise or shock somebody so much that they are unable to react immediately
to try and persuade somebody to stop behaving in a stupid way, sometimes using rough or violent methods

examples.en: Try and talk some sense into her before she makes the wrong decision.
Where would I be without you to knock some sense into my head?

senses.definition: to be very much better than somebody/something

examples.en: She knocks spots off all the other candidates.

idioms.word: knock the stuffing out of somebody

senses.definition: to make somebody lose their confidence and enthusiasm

idioms.word: you could have knocked me down with a feather

senses.definition: used to express surprise
the sound of somebody hitting a door, window, etc. with their hand or with something hard to attract attention

examples.en: There was a knock at the door.
I was startled by a loud knock on the car window.

senses.definition: a sharp hit from something hard

examples.en: He got a nasty knock on the head.
Knocks and scratches will lower the value of valuable furniture.

senses.definition: a bad experience that makes somebody/something less confident or successful

examples.en: Her confidence took a further knock when she lost her job.
The company has suffered two huge knocks of late.

senses.definition: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it

examples.en: No one knows the answer.
I need to know your name.
The truth about what happened is not yet known.
All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).
I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.
We know from experience that turning a hobby into a business is not easy.
I know for a fact (that) he didn't go to the party.
‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’
‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’
‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’
As you know, Emma and I are old friends.
‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)
‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).
It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.
I knew where he was hiding.
No one knows for sure who did it.
You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?
I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.
I know next to nothing (= know almost nothing) about opera.
I know of someone who can help us.
‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’
Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?
We know her to be honest.
Strobe lights are known to cause seizures.

senses.definition: to realize, understand or be aware of something

examples.en: As soon as I walked in the room I knew (that) something was wrong.
She knew she was dying.
‘Martin was lying all the time.’ ‘I should have known.’
I knew perfectly well what she meant.
I know exactly how you feel.
This case is hopeless and he knows it (= although he will not admit it).

senses.definition: to feel certain about something

examples.en: He knew (that) he could trust her.
I know it's here somewhere!
I know things will turn out all right.
I don't know that I can finish it by next week.
I just knew that it was something I wanted to do.
‘You were right—someone's been spreading rumours about you.’ ‘I knew it!’
‘She's the worst player in the team.’ ‘Oh, I don't know (= I am not sure that I agree)—she played well yesterday.’

senses.definition: to be familiar with a person, place, thing, etc.

examples.en: I've known David for 20 years.
Do you two know each other (= have you met before)?
She was a secretary when I first knew her.
She's very nice when you get to know her.
Knowing Ben, we could be waiting a long time (= it is typical of him to be late).
This man is known to the police (= as a criminal).
I don’t know anyone in Oxford.
I know Paris well.
Do you know the play (= have you seen or read it before)?
How many of your neighbours do you know by name?
The new rules could mean the end of football as we know it (= in the form that we are familiar with).

senses.definition: to have learned a skill or language and be able to use it

examples.en: Do you know any Japanese?
Do you know how to use spreadsheets?

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something is a particular type of person or thing or has particular characteristics

examples.en: He has become widely known as an expert in child psychology.
It's known as the most dangerous part of the city.
She is best known for her work on the human brain.
He is internationally known for his work with vaccines.
He's known to be an outstanding physicist.

senses.definition: to give somebody/something a particular name or title

examples.en: Iran was formerly known as Persia.
The H5N1 virus is more commonly known as bird flu.
Peter Wilson, also known as ‘The Tiger’

examples.cf: be known as somebody/something to somebody
examples.en: He was known as Bonzo to his friends.
The country was not yet known by the name of England.

senses.definition: to be able to recognize somebody/something

examples.en: I couldn't see who was speaking, but I knew the voice.
She knows a bargain when she sees one.

senses.definition: to understand the difference between one person or thing and another

examples.en: I hope we have taught our children to know right from wrong.

senses.definition: to have seen, heard or experienced something

examples.en: I’ve never known it (to) snow in July before.
He has been known to spend all morning in the bathroom.

senses.definition: to have personal experience of something

examples.en: He has known both poverty and wealth.
She may be successful now, but she has known what it is like to be poor.
She thought she would never know the joy of seeing a child grow up in her care.

idioms.word: as far as I know | as far as I can remember, see, tell, etc.

senses.definition: used to say that you think you know, remember, understand, etc. something but you cannot be completely sure, especially because you do not know all the facts

examples.en: As far as we knew, there was no cause for concern.
As far as I can see, you've done nothing wrong.
She lived in Chicago, as far as I can remember.

idioms.word: before you know where you are

senses.definition: very quickly or suddenly

examples.en: We were whisked off in a taxi before we knew where we were.

senses.definition: to have no way of realizing or being aware that you have done something wrong

examples.en: ‘I'm sorry, I called when you were in bed.’ ‘Don't worry—you weren't to know.’

idioms.word: better the devil you know (than the devil you don’t)

senses.definition: used to say that it is easier and wiser to stay in a bad situation that you know and can deal with rather than change to a new situation that may be much worse

idioms.word: for all you, I, they, etc. know

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you do not know something and that it is not important to you

examples.en: She could be dead for all I know.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you do not know something

examples.en: God knows what else they might find.
‘Where are they?’ ‘Goodness knows.’

senses.definition: used to emphasize the truth of what you are saying

examples.en: She ought to pass the exam—goodness knows she's been working hard enough.

senses.definition: to be confident that you know something, especially when you actually do not

examples.en: He thinks he knows all the answers.

variants.text: (North American English have/know something down pat)
variants.html: (North American English have/know something down pat)

senses.definition: to know something perfectly so that you can repeat it at any time without having to think about it

examples.en: He had all the answers off pat.

senses.definition: to be in poor condition

examples.en: Our car has seen better days!

idioms.word: I don’t know how, why, etc…

senses.definition: used to criticize somebody’s behaviour

examples.en: I don't know how you can say things like that.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody the true facts about a situation, especially when these are not known by other people

examples.en: If the truth be known, I was afraid to tell anyone.

senses.definition: used to agree with somebody or to show sympathy

examples.en: ‘What a ridiculous situation!’ ‘I know.’

senses.definition: used to introduce a new idea or suggestion

examples.en: I know, let's see what's on at the theatre.

idioms.word: know something as well as I do

senses.definition: used to criticize somebody by saying that they should realize or understand something

examples.en: You know as well as I do that you're being unreasonable.

senses.definition: to know somebody/something extremely well

examples.en: She must know the play backwards by now.

senses.definition: to know what should be done, etc. better than other people

examples.en: The doctor told you to stay in bed, and she knows best.

idioms.word: know better (than that/than to do something)

senses.definition: to be sensible enough not to do something

examples.en: He knows better than to judge by appearances.

senses.definition: to recognize somebody without knowing them well
to have information or evidence that the opposite is true

examples.en: He says he doesn't care about what the critics write, but I know different.

senses.definition: to be very aware of a fact and unable to deny or ignore it

examples.en: He knew full well what she thought of it.

idioms.word: know somebody/something inside out | know somebody/something like the back of your hand

senses.definition: to be very familiar with somebody/something

examples.en: This is where I grew up. I know this area like the back of my hand.

senses.definition: to have very clear and definite ideas about what you want to do
to know a lot about a particular subject or job

idioms.word: know/tell somebody a thing or two (about somebody/something)

senses.definition: to know/tell somebody some useful, interesting or surprising information about somebody/something

examples.en: She's been married five times, so she knows a thing or two about men!

senses.definition: to know something because of something unpleasant that has happened to you

examples.en: She is a tough competitor, as I know to my cost.

senses.definition: to be familiar with a place, subject, etc.
to have knowledge about something from your own experience

examples.en: I worked there for 20 years, so I know what I'm talking about.

idioms.word: know which side your bread is buttered

senses.definition: to know where you can get an advantage for yourself

idioms.word: let it be known/make it known that…

senses.definition: to make sure that people are informed about something, especially by getting somebody else to tell them

examples.en: The President has let it be known that he does not intend to run for election again.

senses.definition: to tell somebody about something

examples.en: I don't know if I can come, but I'll let you know tomorrow.
Let me know how I can help.
Please let me know if there's anything I can do to help.

senses.definition: used to emphasize what you are saying

examples.en: Lord knows, I tried to teach her.

senses.definition: used to say that you do not know the answer to something

examples.en: ‘Why did she say that?’ ‘Lord knows!’

senses.definition: to introduce yourself to somebody

examples.en: I made myself known to the hotel manager.

senses.definition: to behave badly, usually because you have not been taught the correct way to behave

examples.en: Don’t blame the children—they don’t know any better.

idioms.word: not know your arse from your elbow

senses.definition: to be very stupid; to have absolutely no skill
to know nothing about a subject

examples.en: I don’t know beans about making movies.

idioms.word: not know the first thing about somebody/something

senses.definition: to know nothing at all about somebody/something

examples.en: I’m afraid I don’t know the first thing about cars.

idioms.word: not know, etc. the first thing about something/somebody

senses.definition: to know nothing at all about something/somebody

examples.en: We’ve lived next to him for years, but we still don’t know the first thing about him.

senses.definition: to not know at all who somebody is
to be so surprised by something that you do not know how to react
to feel very embarrassed and not know how to react

idioms.word: not know whether you’re coming or going

senses.definition: to be so excited or confused that you cannot behave or think in a sensible way
to have an easy life without realizing how easy it is

examples.en: You people without kids don't know you're born.

senses.definition: to take no interest in something because you do not care about it or it is too much trouble

examples.en: I've tried to ask her advice, but she doesn't want to know (= about my problems).
‘How much was it?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= it is better if you don't know).

senses.definition: old enough to behave in a more sensible way than you actually did
to show somebody/know/learn how a particular job should be done
used to say that it is impossible to say what might happen

examples.en: There's no knowing how he'll react.

senses.definition: used to say that somebody knows nothing about the subject you are talking about

examples.en: What does he know about football, anyway?

senses.definition: used to express surprise

examples.en: Well, what do you know? Look who's here!

senses.definition: (know) what things are useful, important, etc.

examples.en: She certainly knows what's what.

senses.definition: used when you are thinking of what to say next

examples.en: Well, you know, it's difficult to explain.

senses.definition: used to show that what you are referring to is known or understood by the person you are speaking to

examples.en: Guess who I've just seen? Maggie! You know—Jim's wife.
You know that restaurant round the corner? It's closed down.

senses.definition: used to emphasize something that you are saying

examples.en: I'm not stupid, you know.

senses.definition: used to introduce an interesting or surprising opinion, piece of news, etc.

examples.en: You know something? I've never really enjoyed Christmas.

senses.definition: used to refer to somebody/something without mentioning a name
used to say that you can never be certain about what will happen in the future, especially when you are suggesting that something good might happen
having more information about something than most people

examples.en: Somebody in the know told me he's going to resign.

senses.definition: the information, understanding and skills that you gain through education or experience

examples.en: scientific/technical knowledge and skills
intimate/first-hand/basic knowledge
a thirst for knowledge
It will be an opportunity to gain knowledge and experience.
She has acquired a detailed knowledge of the subject.
They enjoy sharing their knowledge of the business.
He had no prior knowledge of the language before visiting the country.
He has a wide knowledge of painting and music.
There is a lack of knowledge about the tax system.

senses.definition: the state of knowing about a particular fact or situation

examples.en: He denied all knowledge of the affair.
She sent the letter without my knowledge.
The film was made with the Prince's full knowledge and approval.
I was happy in the knowledge that I had done my best.
I went to sleep secure in the knowledge that I was not alone in the house.
They could relax safe in the knowledge that they had the funding for the project.
Their delight in the win was tempered by the knowledge that the competition would only get fiercer.

senses.definition: information, considered as a resource to be used and supplied in industry, rather than producing goods

examples.en: the shift toward a knowledge economy
Knowledge workers are driving our economy today.
the emergence of consultancy as a knowledge industry
knowledge capital/assets
The successful candidate will have experience in data and knowledge management.

senses.definition: to be something that everyone knows, especially in a particular community or group

examples.en: Their relationship is common knowledge.

senses.definition: to become known by somebody

examples.en: It has come to our knowledge that you have been taking time off without permission.

idioms.word: to the best of your knowledge/belief

senses.definition: as far as you know

examples.en: He never made a will, to the best of my knowledge.

senses.definition: from the information you have, although you may not know everything

examples.en: ‘Are they divorced?’ ‘Not to my knowledge.’
She never, to my knowledge, considered resigning.
